column2: title=Sotheby's Valuable Printed Books and Manuscripts 13 December 2001
image=[[File:Sotheby's Valuable Printed Books and Manuscripts 13 December 2001.jpg

column1: '''''Sotheby's Valuable Printed Books and Manuscripts 13 December 2001''''' is an auction catalogue from [[Sotheby's]] (London). This catalogue includes several Tolkien-related lots, the most notable being:<ref>{{webcite

*Lot 546 (p.256) - Tolkien's annotated personal copy of the two volume ''Shorter Oxford English Dictionary''. Two notes are reproduced in photographs - one is associated with the entry for 'Fairy', while the other is a definition for 'Bag-end'.
*Lot 549 (p.259) - A specially bound first edition set of ''The Lord of the Rings''. The lot description quotes from a letter and [[Letter to Peter Alford (1956-58)
column2: note by Tolkien to Peter Alford]] regarding titles for each of the six books.

column1: *Lot 550 (pp.260-1) - A group of four letters to Peter Alford ([[Letter to Peter Alford (14 January 1956)
column5: 2 April 1958]]). The lot description includes quotes discussing ''The Lord of the Rings'' and a visit to Holland for a 'Hobbit Dinner'. Six pages from the letters are reproduced in a photograph.

column1: *Lot 552 (pp.262-3) - A letter to [[Letter to Pauline Baynes
column2: Pauline Baynes dated 4 June 1949]] - The lot description includes extracts mentioning ''Farmer Giles of Ham'' and ''The Lord of the Rings''. The first page of the letter is reproduced in a photograph.

column1: *Lot 554 (pp.264-5) - Four letters to Pauline Baynes dating from 23 November 1961 to 3 August 1962 - the lot description includes quotes discussing ''The Adventures of Tom Bombadil''. Five pages from the letters are reproduced in a photograph. (This lot was offered again in a later Sotheby's catalogue, see Lot 789, ''[[Sotheby's Literature and Illustration 11-12 July 2002]]'')
*Lot 557 (p.266) - A letter to [[Letter to Anthony D. Howlett
column2: Anthony D. Howlett dated 28 May 1969]] - The lot description includes extracts discussing the name 'Rivendell'. The first page of the letter is reproduced in a photograph.
